stacks.title: If You Loved Mother of Learning, Read These Next
stacks.description: Time loops, magic systems, and clever protagonists.
stacks.curatorNote: Mother of Learning set the gold standard for time loop fiction. These stories share its DNA: intelligent protagonists who learn from their mistakes, intricate magic systems worth exploring, and that satisfying sense of earned progress. Each one gave me the same feeling of 'just one more chapter' that MoL did.

entries.curatorNote: The gold standard. If you somehow haven't read this yet, start here.
What if Joffrey Baratheon got a redemption arc through a time loop? Sounds crazy, but it works brilliantly. The character development is phenomenal.
A more lighthearted take on time loops. Ryan's humor masks genuine depth, and the superhero setting is fresh.
Not a time loop, but scratches the same itch: a rational protagonist dissecting a fantasy world's rules. More meta and introspective.

stacks.title: Hidden Gems on SpaceBattles
stacks.description: Forum legends and hard sci-fi epics.
stacks.curatorNote: SpaceBattles' forum format makes discovery hard, but the quality ceiling is incredibly high. These are the stories that made me lose sleep, buried in forum threads at 3 AM. Most never made it to Royal Road, so you'll need to brave the forum format—but trust me, it's worth it.

entries.curatorNote: The story that launched a thousand fanfics. Taylor's journey from bullied teenager to... well, no spoilers. This changed what web fiction could be.
Yes, it's on this list too. The SpaceBattles version has the best discussion threads for theorycrafting.

stacks.title: Completed & Bingeable
stacks.curatorNote: Nothing worse than getting invested in a story only to find it's been on hiatus for two years. Every story on this list is COMPLETE. Pick one, clear your weekend, and enjoy the ride from start to finish.

entries.curatorNote: 108 chapters of perfection. Plan for a week of lost sleep.
1.7 million words. Yes, really. But once you start, you won't want to stop.
A satisfying ending that stuck the landing. Rare in web fiction.
Shorter than most on this list, but every chapter counts. Great for a long weekend.
3 million words of comfort food progression fantasy. Perfect for when you want something long and satisfying.
Recently completed! The ending was worth the wait.

stacks.title: Kingdom Builders & Base Builders
stacks.description: Stories where you build something that lasts.
stacks.curatorNote: There's something deeply satisfying about watching a protagonist build from nothing. Whether it's a kingdom, a dungeon, or literally just a tree that grows into an empire—these stories deliver that slow-burn satisfaction of seeing something grow.

entries.curatorNote: It starts as a girl running an inn. It becomes so much more. The worldbuilding is unmatched.
Reincarnated as a tree. Sounds weird. Becomes epic. The long-term planning across centuries is *chef's kiss*.
